bug.author: Hermes981128
bug.summary: No matching distribution found for cipheycore<0.3.0,>=0.2.8 (from ciphey)
bug.description: I reported the following errors when I installed using pip. ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement cipheycore<0.3.0,>=0.2.8 (from ciphey) (from versions: 0.0.1, 0.1.0) ERROR: No matching distribution found for cipheycore<0.3.0,>=0.2.8 (from ciphey) <denchmark-link:https://camo.githubusercontent.com/44269f896aade64e161217d05e523520e672050ac03e31a5ea4059a9e8f80789/68747470733a2f2f6865726d65733938313132382e6f73732d636e2d7368616e676861692e616c6979756e63732e636f6d2f313539363435353138383236322e706e67></denchmark-link>

Are you using Python 2, or Python 3? Ciphey only supports Python 3 :) If you are using python 3, please update pip for python 3 with python3 -m pip install --upgrade pip
Maybe the mirror list you use has not already synced the latest version of cipheycore. You can install it with pypi now or wait a while.
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/Cyclic3>@Cyclic3</denchmark-link> do you have any knowledge?

Same issue just now. 64 bit Windows 10 1903, running Python 3.8.5. No other versions of Python installed. <denchmark-code>python -m pip install ciphey Collecting ciphey Using cached ciphey-5.0.0-py3-none-any.whl (50 kB) Collecting pyyaml<6.0.0,>=5.3.1 Using cached PyYAML-5.3.1-cp38-cp38-win32.whl (199 kB) Collecting yaspin<0.18.0,>=0.17.0 Using cached yaspin-0.17.0-py2.py3-none-any.whl (43 kB) Collecting click<8.0.0,>=7.1.2 Downloading click-7.1.2-py2.py3-none-any.whl (82 kB) |â–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆâ–ˆ| 82 kB 446 kB/s Collecting click-spinner<0.2.0,>=0.1.10 Using cached click_spinner-0.1.10-py2.py3-none-any.whl (4.0 kB) ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement cipheycore<0.3.0,>=0.2.8 (from ciphey) (from versions: 0.0.1, 0.1.0) ERROR: No matching distribution found for cipheycore<0.3.0,>=0.2.8 (from ciphey) </denchmark-code>

Hey <denchmark-link:https://github.com/wcg-jrogers>@wcg-jrogers</denchmark-link> ! I'm not dev of CipheyCore, but what happens if you try to install CipheyCore manually? <denchmark-code>pip install cipheycore==0.2.9 </denchmark-code>
:)

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/brandonskerritt>@brandonskerritt</denchmark-link>
<denchmark-code>C:\Windows\system32>pip install cipheycore==0.2.9 ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement cipheycore==0.2.9 (from versions: 0.0.1, 0.1.0) ERROR: No matching distribution found for cipheycore==0.2.9
C:\Windows\system32>pip install cipheycore==0.2.8 ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement cipheycore==0.2.8 (from versions: 0.0.1, 0.1.0) ERROR: No matching distribution found for cipheycore==0.2.8
C:\Windows\system32>pip install cipheycore==0.1.0 Collecting cipheycore==0.1.0 </denchmark-code>
Installing 0.1.0 works but still doesn't allow Ciphey to install :/

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/Ciphey/Ciphey/issues/234>#234</denchmark-link> was a similar problem, and was solved by a mixture of updating pip and installing python from the windows app store. Do either (or both) of these work for you?

<denchmark-link:https://github.com/Cyclic3>@Cyclic3</denchmark-link> Installing Python 3.8 from the Windows store (on TOP of my manually installed 3.8.5), then running fixed the issue and I can now run ciphey. Weird thing is that running the same command with "python" instead of "python3" fails, despite being the exact same version (3.8.5). Ah, I see the difference: <denchmark-code>C:\Windows\system32>python -c "import sys; print(sys.version)" 3.8.5 (tags/v3.8.5:580fbb0, Jul 20 2020, 15:43:08) [MSC v.1926 32 bit (Intel)]
C:\Windows\system32>python3 -c "import sys; print(sys.version)" 3.8.5 (tags/v3.8.5:580fbb0, Jul 20 2020, 15:57:54) [MSC v.1924 64 bit (AMD64)] </denchmark-code>
Looks like the 32-bit python will fail to install the current ciphercore library, and the 32-bit version is what you get from the installer at python.org.
That's a really odd decision from python! I'll take a look at making a 32-bit build, so that this is more fluid in the future!
